title: Mobile, Alabama
text:
Mobile ( , ) is the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Mobile%20County%2C%20Alabama">Mobile County, Alabama</a>, United States. The population within the city limits was 195,111 as of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 United States Census</a>, making it the third-most-populous city in Alabama, and the most populous in Mobile County.
Alabama's only saltwater port, Mobile is located on the <a href="Mobile%20River">Mobile River</a> at the head of the <a href="Mobile%20Bay">Mobile Bay</a> and the north-central Gulf Coast. The <a href="Port%20of%20Mobile">Port of Mobile</a> has always played a key role in the economic health of the city, beginning with the settlement as an important trading center between the <a href="French%20colonization%20of%20the%20Americas">French colonists</a> and <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a>, down to its current role as the 12th-largest port in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
Mobile is the principal municipality of the <a href="Mobile%20metropolitan%20area">Mobile metropolitan area</a>. This region of 412,992 residents is composed solely of Mobile County; it is the third-largest metropolitan statistical area in the state. Mobile is the largest city in the Mobile–<a href="Daphne%2C%20Alabama">Daphne</a>−<a href="Fairhope%2C%20Alabama">Fairhope</a> <a href="Combined%20Statistical%20Area">CSA</a>, with a total population of 604,726, the second largest in the state. , the population within a radius of Mobile is 1,262,907.
Mobile was founded in 1702 by the <a href="Early%20modern%20France">French</a> as the first capital of <a href="Louisiana%20%28New%20France%29">Louisiana</a>. During its first 100 years, Mobile was a colony of <a href="Early%20Modern%20France">France</a>, then <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Britain</a>, and lastly <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. Mobile became a part of the United States in 1813, with the annexation by President <a href="James%20Madison">James Madison</a> of <a href="West%20Florida">West Florida</a> from Spain. The city surrendered to Federal forces on April 12, 1865, after <a href="Union%20%28American%20Civil%20War%29">Union</a> victories at two forts protecting the city. This, along with the news of <a href="Joseph%20E.%20Johnston">Johnston</a>'s surrender negotiations with <a href="William%20Tecumseh%20Sherman">Sherman</a>, led <a href="Richard%20Taylor%20%28Confederate%20general%29">Taylor</a> to seek a meeting with his Union counterpart, Maj. Gen. <a href="Edward%20Canby">Edward R. S. Canby</a>. The two generals met several miles north of Mobile on May 2. After agreeing to a 48-hour <a href="Ceasefire">truce</a>, the generals enjoyed an <a href="Al%20fresco%20dining">al fresco luncheon</a> of food, drink, and lively music. Canby offered Taylor the same terms agreed upon between <a href="Robert%20E.%20Lee">Lee</a> and <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Grant</a>. Taylor accepted the terms and surrendered his command on May 4 at <a href="Citronelle%2C%20Alabama">Citronelle, Alabama</a>.
Considered one of the <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">Gulf Coast</a>'s cultural centers, Mobile has several art museums, a symphony orchestra, professional opera, professional ballet company, and a large concentration of historic architecture. Mobile is known for having the oldest organized <a href="Carnival">Carnival</a> or <a href="Mardi%20Gras">Mardi Gras</a> celebrations in the United States. Its French Catholic colonial settlers celebrated this festival from the first decade of the 18th century. Beginning in 1830, Mobile was host to the first formally organized Carnival <a href="mystic%20society">mystic society</a> to celebrate with a parade in the United States. (In New Orleans, such a group is called a "krewe".)
Etymology.
The city gained its name from the Mobile tribe that the French colonists encountered living in the area of <a href="Mobile%20Bay">Mobile Bay</a>. Although debated by Alabama historians, they may have been descendants of the Native American tribe whose small fortress town, <a href="Mabila">Mabila</a>, was used to conceal several thousand native warriors before an attack in 1540 on the expedition of Spanish explorer <a href="Hernando%20de%20Soto">Hernando de Soto</a>. About seven years after the founding of the French Mobile settlement, the Mobile tribe, along with the Tohomé, gained permission from the colonists to settle near the fort.
History.
Colonial.
The European settlement of Mobile began with French colonists, who in 1702 constructed "<a href="Old%20Mobile%20Site">Fort Louis de la Louisiane</a>", at Twenty-seven Mile Bluff on the <a href="Mobile%20River">Mobile River</a>, as the first capital of the <a href="French%20colonial%20empires">French colony</a> of <a href="Louisiana%20%28New%20France%29">La Louisiane</a>. It was founded by <a href="French%20Canadian">French Canadian</a> brothers <a href="Pierre%20Le%20Moyne%20d%27Iberville">Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville</a> and <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20Le%20Moyne%2C%20Sieur%20de%20Bienville">Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville</a>, to establish control over France's claims to "La Louisiane". Bienville was appointed as royal governor of French Louisiana in 1701. Mobile's Roman Catholic parish was established on July 20, 1703, by <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20de%20la%20Croix%20de%20Chevri%C3%A8res%20de%20Saint-Vallier">Jean-Baptiste de la Croix de Chevrières de Saint-Vallier</a>, <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Quebec">Bishop of Quebec</a>. The parish was the first French Catholic parish established on the <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">Gulf Coast of the United States</a>.
In 1704 the <a href="French%20ship%20P%C3%A9lican%20%281702%29">ship "Pélican"</a> delivered 23 Frenchwomen to the colony; passengers had contracted <a href="yellow%20fever">yellow fever</a> at a stop in <a href="Havana">Havana</a>. Though most of the ""Pélican" girls" recovered, numerous colonists and neighboring Native Americans contracted the disease in turn and many died. This early period was also the occasion of the importation of the first African <a href="slaves">slaves</a>, transported aboard a French supply ship from the French colony of <a href="Saint-Domingue">Saint-Domingue</a> in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, where they had first been held. The population of the colony fluctuated over the next few years, growing to 279 persons by 1708, yet shrinking to 178 persons two years later due to disease.
These additional outbreaks of disease and a series of floods resulted in Bienville ordering that the settlement be relocated in 1711 several miles downriver to its present location at the confluence of the <a href="Mobile%20River">Mobile River</a> and <a href="Mobile%20Bay">Mobile Bay</a>. A new earth-and-palisade Fort Louis was constructed at the new site during this time. By 1712, when <a href="Antoine%20Crozat">Antoine Crozat</a> was appointed to take over administration of the colony, its population had reached 400 persons.
The capital of <a href="Louisiana%20%28New%20France%29">La Louisiane</a> was moved in 1720 to <a href="Biloxi%2C%20Mississippi">Biloxi</a>, leaving Mobile to serve as a regional military and trading center. In 1723 the construction of a new brick fort with a stone foundation began and it was renamed Fort Condé in honor of <a href="Louis%20Henri%2C%20Duke%20of%20Bourbon">Louis Henri, Duke of Bourbon</a>.
In 1763, the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Paris%20%281763%29">Treaty of Paris</a> was signed, ending the <a href="Seven%20Years%27%20War">Seven Years' War</a>, which Britain won, defeating France. By this treaty, France ceded its territories east of the Mississippi River to Britain. This area was made a part of the expanded British <a href="West%20Florida">West Florida</a> colony. The British changed the name of Fort Condé to <a href="Fort%20Charlotte%2C%20Mobile">Fort Charlotte</a>, after <a href="Queen%20Charlotte">Queen Charlotte</a>.
The British were eager not to lose any useful inhabitants and promised religious tolerance to the French colonists; ultimately 112 French colonists remained in Mobile. The first permanent Jewish settlers came to Mobile in 1763 as a result of the new British rule and religious tolerance. Jews had not been allowed to officially reside in colonial French Louisiana due to the <a href="Code%20Noir">Code Noir</a>, a decree passed by France's King Louis XIV in 1685 that forbade the exercise of any religion other than Roman Catholicism, and ordered all Jews out of France's colonies. Most of these colonial-era Jews in Mobile were merchants and traders from Sephardic Jewish communities in <a href="Savannah%2C%20Georgia">Savannah, Georgia</a> and <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>; they added to the commercial development of Mobile. In 1766 the total population was estimated to be 860, though the town's borders were smaller than during the French colonial period. During the <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">American Revolutionary War</a>, West Florida and Mobile became a refuge for <a href="Loyalist%20%28American%20Revolution%29">loyalists</a> fleeing the other colonies.
While the British were dealing with their rebellious colonists along the Atlantic coast, the <a href="Spain%20in%20the%20American%20Revolutionary%20War">Spanish entered the war</a> in 1779 as an ally of France. They took the opportunity to order <a href="Bernardo%20de%20G%C3%A1lvez%20y%20Madrid%2C%20Count%20of%20G%C3%A1lvez">Bernardo de Galvez</a>, Governor of Louisiana, on an expedition east to retake West Florida. He captured Mobile during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Fort%20Charlotte">Battle of Fort Charlotte</a> in 1780, as part of this campaign. The Spanish wished to eliminate any British threat to their Louisiana colony west of the Mississippi River, which they had received from France in the 1763 Treaty of Paris. Their actions were condoned by the revolting American colonies, partially evidenced by the presence of Oliver Pollack, representative of the American Continental Congress. Due to strong trade ties, many residents of Mobile and <a href="West%20Florida">West Florida</a> remained loyal to the <a href="British%20Crown">British Crown</a>. The Spanish renamed the fort as Fortaleza Carlota, and held Mobile as a part of Spanish <a href="West%20Florida">West Florida</a> until 1813, when it was seized by United States General <a href="James%20Wilkinson">James Wilkinson</a> during the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>.
19th century.
By the time Mobile was included in the <a href="Mississippi%20Territory">Mississippi Territory</a> in 1813, the population had dwindled to roughly 300 people. The city was included in the <a href="Alabama%20Territory">Alabama Territory</a> in 1817, after <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a> gained statehood. Alabama was granted statehood in 1819; Mobile's population had increased to 809 by that time.
Mobile was well situated for trade, as its location tied it to a river system that served as the principal navigational access for most of Alabama and a large part of Mississippi. River transportation was aided by the introduction of <a href="steamboat">steamboat</a>s in the early decades of the 19th century. By 1822 the city's population was 2800.
The <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> in Great Britain created shortages of cotton, driving up prices on world markets. Much land well suited to growing cotton lies in the vicinity of the <a href="Mobile%20River">Mobile River</a>, and its main tributaries the <a href="Tombigbee%20River">Tombigbee</a> and <a href="Alabama%20River">Alabama River</a>s. A <a href="plantation%20economy">plantation economy</a> using slave labor developed in the region and as a consequence Mobile's population quickly grew. It came to be settled by attorneys, <a href="cotton%20factor">cotton factor</a>s, doctors, merchants and other professionals seeking to capitalize on trade with the upriver areas.
From the 1830s onward, Mobile expanded into a city of commerce with a primary focus on the cotton and slave trades. Many slaves were transported by ship in the <a href="coastwise%20slave%20trade">coastwise slave trade</a> from the Upper South. There were many businesses in the city related to the slave trade – people to make clothes, food, and supplies for the slave traders and their wards. The city's booming businesses attracted merchants from the North; by 1850 10% of its population was from <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, which was deeply involved in the cotton industry. Mobile was the slave-trading center of the state until the 1850s, when it was surpassed by <a href="Montgomery%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery</a>.
The prosperity stimulated a building boom that was underway by the mid-1830s, with the building of some of the most elaborate structures the city had seen up to that point. This was cut short in part by the <a href="Panic%20of%201837">Panic of 1837</a> and <a href="yellow%20fever">yellow fever</a> epidemics. The waterfront was developed with wharves, terminal facilities, and fireproof brick warehouses. The exports of cotton grew in proportion to the amounts being produced in the <a href="Black%20Belt%20%28region%20of%20Alabama%29">Black Belt</a>; by 1840 Mobile was second only to <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> in cotton exports in the nation.
With the economy so focused on one crop, Mobile's fortunes were always tied to those of cotton, and the city weathered many financial crises. Mobile slaveholders owned relatively few slaves compared to planters in the upland <a href="Plantations%20in%20the%20American%20South">plantation</a> areas, but many households had domestic slaves, and many other slaves worked on the waterfront and on riverboats. The last slaves to enter the United States from the African trade were brought to Mobile on the slave ship <a href="Clotilda%20%28slave%20ship%29">"Clotilda"</a>. Among them was <a href="Cudjoe%20Lewis">Cudjoe Lewis</a>, who in the 1920s became the last survivor of the slave trade.
By 1853, fifty Jewish families lived in Mobile, including <a href="Philip%20Phillips%20%28lawyer%29">Philip Phillips</a>, an attorney from <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>, who was elected to the Alabama State Legislature and then to the United States Congress. Many early Jewish families were descendants of Sephardic Jews who had been among the earliest colonial settlers in Charleston and Savannah.
By 1860 Mobile's population within the city limits had reached 29,258 people; it was the 27th-largest city in the United States and 4th-largest in what would soon be the <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate States of America</a>. The free population in the whole of Mobile County, including the city, consisted of 29,754 citizens, of which 1,195 were <a href="Person%20of%20color">free people of color</a>. Additionally, 1,785 slave owners in the county held 11,376 people in bondage, about one-quarter of the total county population of 41,130 people.
During the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, Mobile was a Confederate city. The "<a href="H.%20L.%20Hunley%20%28submarine%29">H. L. Hunley</a>", the first <a href="submarine">submarine</a> to sink an enemy ship, was built in Mobile. One of the most famous <a href="naval%20engagement">naval engagement</a>s of the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">war</a> was the <a href="Battle%20of%20Mobile%20Bay">Battle of Mobile Bay</a>, resulting in the <a href="Union%20%28American%20Civil%20War%29">Union</a> taking control of <a href="Mobile%20Bay">Mobile Bay</a> on August 5, 1864. On April 12, 1865, three days after <a href="Robert%20E.%20Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>'s surrender at <a href="Battle%20of%20Appomattox%20Courthouse">Appomattox Courthouse</a>, the city surrendered to the <a href="Union%20army">Union army</a> to avoid destruction after Union victories at nearby <a href="Battle%20of%20Spanish%20Fort">Spanish Fort</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20Fort%20Blakely">Fort Blakely</a>.
On May 25, 1865, the city suffered great loss when some three hundred people died as a result of an <a href="Mobile%20magazine%20explosion">explosion</a> at a <a href="Federal%20government%20of%20the%20United%20States">federal</a> <a href="ammunition%20depot">ammunition depot</a> on Beauregard Street. The explosion left a deep hole at the depot's location, and sank ships docked on the Mobile River; the resulting fires destroyed the northern portion of the city.
Federal <a href="Reconstruction%20era%20of%20the%20United%20States">Reconstruction</a> in Mobile began after the Civil War and effectively ended in 1874 when the local <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrats</a> gained control of the city government. The last quarter of the 19th century was a time of economic depression and municipal insolvency for Mobile. One example can be provided by the value of Mobile's exports during this period of depression. The value of exports leaving the city fell from $9 million in 1878 to $3 million in 1882.
20th century.
The turn of the 20th century brought the <a href="Progressive%20Era">Progressive Era</a> to Mobile. The economic structure developed with new industries, generating new jobs and attracting a significant increase in population. The population increased from around 40,000 in 1900 to 60,000 by 1920. During this time the city received $3 million in federal grants for harbor improvements to deepen the shipping channels. During and after World War I, manufacturing became increasingly vital to Mobile's economic health, with shipbuilding and steel production being two of the most important industries.
During this time, social justice and race relations in Mobile worsened, however. The state passed a new constitution in 1901 that <a href="Disfranchisement%20after%20Reconstruction%20era">disenfranchised most blacks and many poor whites</a>; and the white Democratic-dominated legislature passed other discriminatory legislation. In 1902, the city government passed Mobile's first <a href="racial%20segregation">racial segregation</a> ordinance, segregating the city streetcars. It legislated what had been informal practice, enforced by convention. Mobile's African-American population responded to this with a two-month boycott, but the law was not repealed. After this, Mobile's "de facto" segregation was increasingly replaced with legislated segregation as whites imposed <a href="Jim%20Crow%20laws">Jim Crow laws</a> to maintain <a href="white%20supremacy">supremacy</a>.
In 1911 the city adopted a commission form of government, which had three members elected by <a href="at-large">at-large</a> voting. Considered to be progressive, as it would reduce the power of ward bosses, this change resulted in the elite white majority strengthening its power, as only the majority could gain election of at-large candidates. In addition, poor whites and blacks had already been disenfranchised. Mobile was one of the last cities to retain this form of government, which prevented smaller groups from electing candidates of their choice. But Alabama's white yeomanry had historically favored <a href="single-member%20districts">single-member districts</a> in order to elect candidates of their choice.
The <a href="red%20imported%20fire%20ant">red imported fire ant</a> was first introduced into the United States via the Port of Mobile. Sometime in the late 1930s they came ashore off cargo ships arriving from South America. The ants were carried in the soil used as ballast on those ships. They have spread throughout the South and Southwest.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the defense buildup in Mobile shipyards resulted in a considerable increase in the city's white middle-class and working-class population, largely due to the massive influx of workers coming to work in the shipyards and at the <a href="Brookley%20Air%20Force%20Base">Brookley Army Air Field</a>. Between 1940 and 1943, more than 89,000 people moved into Mobile to work for war effort industries.
Mobile was one of eighteen United States cities producing <a href="Liberty%20ships">Liberty ships</a>. Its <a href="Alabama%20Drydock%20and%20Shipbuilding%20Company">Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company</a> (ADDSCO) supported the war effort by producing ships faster than the <a href="Axis%20powers%20of%20World%20War%20II">Axis powers</a> could sink them. ADDSCO also churned out a copious number of <a href="T2%20tanker">T2 tanker</a>s for the War Department. <a href="Gulf%20Shipbuilding%20Corporation">Gulf Shipbuilding Corporation</a>, a subsidiary of <a href="Waterman%20Steamship%20Corporation">Waterman Steamship Corporation</a>, focused on building <a href="Cargo%20ship">freighters</a>, s, and <a href="Minesweeper%20%28ship%29">minesweepers</a>. The rapid increase of population in the city produced crowded conditions, increasing social tensions in the competition for housing and good jobs.
A <a href="race%20riot">race riot</a> broke out in May 1943 of whites against blacks. ADDSCO management had long maintained segregated conditions at the shipyards, although the Roosevelt administration had ordered defense contractors to integrate facilities. That year ADDSCO promoted 12 blacks to positions as welders, previously reserved for whites; and whites objected to the change by rioting on May 24. The mayor appealed to the governor to call in the <a href="National%20Guard%20%28United%20States%29">National Guard</a> to restore order, but it was weeks before officials allowed African Americans to return to work, keeping them away for their safety.
In the late 1940s, the transition to the postwar economy was hard for the city, as thousands of jobs were lost at the shipyards with the decline in the defense industry. Eventually the city's social structure began to become more liberal. Replacing shipbuilding as a primary economic force, the paper and chemical industries began to expand. No longer needed for defense, most of the old military bases were converted to civilian uses. Following the war, in which many African Americans had served, veterans and their supporters stepped up activism to gain enforcement of their constitutional rights and social justice, especially in the <a href="Jim%20Crow">Jim Crow</a> South. During the 1950s the City of Mobile integrated its police force and <a href="Spring%20Hill%20College">Spring Hill College</a> accepted students of all races. Unlike in the rest of the state, by the early 1960s the city buses and lunch counters voluntarily desegregated.
The Alabama legislature passed the Cater Act in 1949, allowing cities and counties to set up industrial development boards (IDB) to issue municipal bonds as incentives to attract new industry into their local areas. The city of Mobile did not establish a Cater Act board until 1962. <a href="George%20E.%20McNally">George E. McNally</a>, Mobile's first Republican mayor since Reconstruction, was the driving force behind the founding of the IDB. The Mobile Area Chamber of Commerce, believing its members were better qualified to attract new businesses and industry to the area, considered the new IDB as a serious rival. After several years of political squabbling, the Chamber of Commerce emerged victorious. While McNally's IDB prompted the Chamber of Commerce to become more proactive in attracting new industry, the chamber effectively shut Mobile city government out of economic development decisions.
In 1963, three African-American students brought a case against the Mobile County School Board for being denied admission to <a href="Murphy%20High%20School%2C%20Alabama">Murphy High School</a>. This was nearly a decade after the United States Supreme Court had ruled in "<a href="Brown%20v.%20Board%20of%20Education">Brown v. Board of Education</a>" (1954) that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional. The federal district court ordered that the three students be admitted to Murphy for the 1964 school year, leading to the desegregation of Mobile County's school system.
The <a href="civil%20rights%20movement">civil rights movement</a> gained congressional passage of the <a href="Civil%20Rights%20Act%20of%201964">Civil Rights Act of 1964</a> and <a href="Voting%20Rights%20Act%20of%201965">Voting Rights Act of 1965</a>, eventually ending legal segregation and regaining effective suffrage for African Americans. But whites in the state had more than one way to reduce African Americans' voting power. Maintaining the city commission form of government with <a href="at-large">at-large</a> voting resulted in all positions being elected by the white majority, as African Americans could not command a majority for their candidates in the informally segregated city.
In 1969 <a href="Brookley%20Air%20Force%20Base">Brookley Air Force Base</a> was closed by the Department of Defense, dealing Mobile's economy a severe blow. The closing resulted in a 10% unemployment rate in the city. This and other factors related to industrial restructuring ushered in a period of economic depression that lasted through the 1970s. The loss of jobs created numerous problems and resulted in loss of population as residents moved away for work.
Mobile's city commission form of government was challenged and finally overturned in 1982 in "<a href="City%20of%20Mobile%20v.%20Bolden">City of Mobile v. Bolden</a>", which was remanded by the <a href="United%20States%20Supreme%20Court">United States Supreme Court</a> to the district court. Finding that the city had adopted a commission form of government in 1911 and <a href="at-large">at-large</a> positions with discriminatory intent, the court proposed that the three members of the city commission should be elected from <a href="single-member%20districts">single-member districts</a>, likely ending their division of executive functions among them. Mobile's state legislative delegation in 1985 finally enacted a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government, with seven members elected from <a href="single-member%20districts">single-member districts</a>. This was approved by voters. As white conservatives increasingly entered the Republican Party in the late 20th century, African-American residents of the city have elected members of the Democratic Party as their candidates of choice. Since the change to single-member districts, more women and African Americans were elected to the council than under the at-large system.
Beginning in the late 1980s, newly elected mayor <a href="Mike%20Dow">Mike Dow</a> and the city council began an effort termed the "String of Pearls Initiative" to make Mobile into a competitive city. The city initiated construction of numerous new facilities and projects, and the restoration of hundreds of historic downtown buildings and homes. City and county leaders also made efforts to attract new business ventures to the area.
Geography and climate.
Geography.
Mobile is located in the southwestern corner of the U.S. state of Alabama. According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , with of it being land, and , or 26.1% of the total, being covered by water. The elevation in Mobile ranges from on Water Street in downtown to at the Mobile Regional Airport.
Neighborhoods.
Mobile has a number of notable historic neighborhoods. These include <a href="Ashland%20Place%20Historic%20District%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Ashland Place</a>, <a href="Campground%20Historic%20District">Campground</a>, <a href="Church%20Street%20East%20Historic%20District">Church Street East</a>, <a href="De%20Tonti%20Square%20Historic%20District">De Tonti Square</a>, <a href="Leinkauf%20Historic%20District">Leinkauf</a>, <a href="Lower%20Dauphin%20Street%20Historic%20District">Lower Dauphin Street</a>, <a href="Midtown%20Historic%20District%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Midtown</a>, <a href="Oakleigh%20Garden%20Historic%20District">Oakleigh Garden</a>, <a href="Old%20Dauphin%20Way%20Historic%20District">Old Dauphin Way</a>, <a href="Spring%20Hill%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Spring Hill</a>, and <a href="Toulminville">Toulminville</a>.
Climate.
Mobile's geographical location on the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> provides a mild <a href="humid%20subtropical%20climate">subtropical climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a> "Cfa"), with hot, humid summers and mild, rainy winters. The record low temperature was , set on February 13, 1899, and the record high was , set on August 29, 2000.
A 2007 study by <a href="Weatherbill">WeatherBill, Inc.</a> determined that Mobile is the wettest city in the contiguous 48 states, with of average annual rainfall over a 30-year period. Mobile averages 120 days per year with at least of rain. Precipitation is heavy year-round. On average, July and August are the wettest months, with frequent and often-heavy shower and thunderstorm activity. October stands out as a slightly drier month than all others. Snow is rare in Mobile, with its last snowfall occurring on December 8, 2017; before this, the last snowfall had been nearly four years earlier, on January 27, 2014.
Mobile is occasionally affected by major tropical storms and hurricanes. The city suffered a major natural disaster on the night of September 12, 1979, when <a href="Saffir%E2%80%93Simpson%20Hurricane%20Scale">category-3</a> <a href="Hurricane%20Frederic">Hurricane Frederic</a> passed over the heart of the city. The storm caused tremendous damage to Mobile and the surrounding area. Mobile had moderate damage from <a href="Hurricane%20Opal">Hurricane Opal</a> on October 4, 1995, and <a href="Hurricane%20Ivan">Hurricane Ivan</a> on September 16, 2004.
Mobile suffered millions of dollars in damage from <a href="Hurricane%20Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a> on August 29, 2005, which damaged much of the Gulf Coast cities. A storm surge of , topped by higher waves, damaged eastern sections of the city with extensive flooding in downtown, the <a href="Battleship%20Parkway">Battleship Parkway</a>, and the elevated <a href="Jubilee%20Parkway">Jubilee Parkway</a>. Christmas Day tornado.
In late December 2012, the city suffered two tornado hits. On December 25, 2012, at 4:54 pm, a large <a href="wedge%20tornado">wedge tornado</a> touched down in the city. The tornado rapidly intensified as it moved north-northeast at speeds of up to . The path took the tornado into <a href="Midtown%20Historic%20District%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Midtown</a>, causing damage or destruction to at least 100 structures. The heaviest damage to houses was along Carlen Street, Rickarby Place, Dauphin Street, <a href="Old%20Shell%20Road">Old Shell Road</a>, Margaret Street, Silverwood Street, and Springhill Avenue. In addition to residential structures, the tornado caused significant damage to the Carmelite Monastery, Little Flower Catholic Church, commercial real estate along <a href="Airport%20Boulevard%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Airport Boulevard</a> and <a href="Government%20Street%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Government Street</a> in the Midtown at the Loop neighborhood, <a href="Murphy%20High%20School%20%28Alabama%29">Murphy High School</a>, <a href="Trinity%20Episcopal%20Church%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Trinity Episcopal Church</a>, <a href="Congregation%20Sha%27arai%20Shomayim%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Springhill Avenue Temple</a>, and Mobile Infirmary Hospital before moving into the neighboring city of Prichard. The tornado was classified as an <a href="Enhanced%20Fujita%20scale">EF2</a> tornado by the <a href="National%20Weather%20Service">National Weather Service</a> on December 26.
The path taken through the city was just a short distance east of the path taken days earlier, on December 20, by an EF1 tornado which had touched down near <a href="Davidson%20High%20School%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Davidson High School</a> and taken a path ending in Prichard. Initial damage estimates for insured and uninsured ranged from $140 to $150 million.
Culture.
Mobile's French and Spanish colonial history has given it a culture distinguished by French, Spanish, Creole, African and Catholic heritage, in addition to later British and American influences. It is distinguished from all other cities in the state of Alabama. The annual <a href="Carnival">Carnival</a> celebration is perhaps the best example of its differences. Mobile is the birthplace of the celebration of <a href="Mardi%20Gras">Mardi Gras</a> in the United States and has the oldest celebration, dating to the early 18th century during the French colonial period.
Carnival in Mobile evolved over the course of 300 years from a beginning as a sedate French Catholic tradition into the mainstream multi-week celebration that today bridges a spectrum of cultures. Mobile's official cultural ambassadors are the <a href="Azalea%20Trail%20Maids">Azalea Trail Maids</a>, meant to embody the ideals of <a href="Southern%20hospitality">Southern hospitality</a>.
"<a href="Close%20Encounters%20of%20the%20Third%20Kind">Close Encounters of the Third Kind</a>" (1977) and "<a href="Back%20Roads%20%281981%20film%29">Back Roads</a>" (1981) were shot in Mobile.
Carnival and Mardi Gras.
The Carnival season has expanded throughout the late fall and winter: <a href="Ball%20%28dance%29">balls</a> in the city may be scheduled as early as November, with the <a href="parade">parade</a>s beginning after January 5 and the Twelfth Day of Christmas or Epiphany on January 6. Carnival celebrations end at midnight on <a href="Mardi%20Gras">Mardi Gras</a>, a moveable feast related to the timing of Lent and Easter. The next day is <a href="Ash%20Wednesday">Ash Wednesday</a> and the beginning of <a href="Lent">Lent</a>, the 40-day penitential season before Easter.
In Mobile, locals often use the term Mardi Gras as a shorthand to refer to the entire Carnival season. During the Carnival season; the <a href="Mystic%20society">mystic societies</a> build colorful floats and parade throughout downtown. Masked society members toss small gifts, known as 'throws,' to parade spectators. The mystic societies, which in essence are exclusive private clubs, also hold formal <a href="masquerade%20ball">masquerade ball</a>s, usually by invitation only, and oriented to adults.
Carnival was first celebrated in Mobile in 1703 when colonial French Catholic settlers carried out their traditional celebration at the <a href="Old%20Mobile%20Site">Old Mobile Site</a>, prior to the 1711 relocation of the city to the current site. Mobile's first Carnival society was established in 1711 with the "Boeuf Gras Society" (Fatted Ox Society). Celebrations were relatively small and consisted of local, private parties until the early 19th century.
In 1830 Mobile's Cowbellion de Rakin Society was the first formally organized and masked mystic society in the United States to celebrate with a parade. The Cowbellions got their start when Michael Krafft, a cotton factor from <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, began a parade with rakes, hoes, and cowbells. The "Cowbellians" introduced horse-drawn floats to the parades in 1840 with a parade entitled "Heathen Gods and Goddesses". The <a href="Striker%27s%20Independent%20Society">Striker's Independent Society</a>, formed in 1843, is the oldest surviving mystic society in the United States.
Carnival celebrations in Mobile were canceled during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. In 1866 <a href="Joe%20Cain">Joe Cain</a> revived the Mardi Gras parades when he paraded through the city streets on Fat Tuesday while costumed as a fictional <a href="Chickasaw">Chickasaw</a> chief named "Slacabamorinico." He celebrated the day in front of the occupying <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> troops. In 2002, Mobile's <a href="Tricentennial">Tricentennial</a> celebrated with parades that represented all of the city's mystic societies.
Founded in 2004, the Conde Explorers in 2005 were the first integrated Mardi Gras society to parade in downtown Mobile. The society has about a hundred members and welcomes men and women of all races. In addition to the parade and ball, the Conde Explorers hold several parties throughout the year. Its members also perform volunteer work. The Conde Explorers were featured in the award-winning documentary, "The Order of Myths" (2008), by <a href="Margaret%20Brown">Margaret Brown</a> about Mobile's Mardi Gras.
Archives and libraries.
The <a href="National%20African%20American%20Archives%20and%20Museum">National African American Archives and Museum</a> features the history of African-American participation in Mardi Gras, authentic artifacts from the era of slavery, and portraits and biographies of famous African Americans. The University of South Alabama Archives houses primary source material relating to the history of Mobile and southern Alabama, as well as the university's history. The archives are located on the ground floor of the USA Spring Hill Campus and are open to the general public.
The Mobile Municipal Archives contains the extant records of the City of Mobile, dating from the city's creation as a municipality by the Mississippi Territory in 1814. The majority of the original records of Mobile's colonial history, spanning the years 1702 through 1813, are housed in Paris, London, <a href="Seville">Seville</a>, and <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>. The Mobile Genealogical Society Library and Media Center is located at the Holy Family Catholic Church and School complex. It features handwritten manuscripts and published materials that are available for use in genealogical research.
The <a href="Mobile%20Public%20Library">Mobile Public Library</a> system serves Mobile and consists of eight branches across Mobile County; its large local history and genealogy division is housed in a facility next to the newly restored and enlarged <a href="Ben%20E.%20May">Ben May</a> Main Library on Government Street. The Saint Ignatius Archives, Museum and Theological Research Library contains primary sources, artifacts, documents, photographs and publications that pertain to the history of Saint Ignatius Church and School, the Catholic history of the city, and the history of the Roman Catholic Church.
Arts and entertainment.
The <a href="Mobile%20Museum%20of%20Art">Mobile Museum of Art</a> features permanent exhibits that span several centuries of art and culture. The museum was expanded in 2002 to approximately . The permanent exhibits include the African and Asian Collection Gallery, Altmayer Gallery (American art), Katharine C. Cochrane Gallery of American Fine Art, Maisel European Gallery, Riddick Glass Gallery, Smith Crafts Gallery, and the Ann B. Hearin Gallery (contemporary works).
The Centre for the Living Arts is an organization that operates the historic <a href="Saenger%20Theatre%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Saenger Theatre</a> and Space 301, a contemporary art gallery. The Saenger Theatre opened in 1927 as a <a href="movie%20palace">movie palace</a>. Today it is a performing arts center and serves as a small concert venue for the city. It is home to the <a href="Mobile%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Mobile Symphony Orchestra</a>, conducted by Maestro Scott Speck. Space 301 Gallery and Studio was initially housed adjacent to the Saenger, but moved to its own space in 2008. The building, donated to the centre by the "<a href="Press-Register">Press-Register</a>" after its relocation to a new modern facility, underwent a $5.2 million renovation and redesign prior to opening. The <a href="Crescent%20Theater">Crescent Theater</a> in downtown Mobile has been showing <a href="arthouse%20film">arthouse film</a>s since 2008.
The <a href="Mobile%20Civic%20Center">Mobile Civic Center</a> contains three facilities under one roof. The building has an arena, a theater and an exposition hall. It is the primary concert venue for the city and hosts a wide variety of events. It is home to the <a href="Mobile%20Opera">Mobile Opera</a> and the Mobile Ballet. The 60-year-old Mobile Opera averages about 1,200 attendees per performance. A wide variety of events are held at Mobile's Arthur C. Outlaw Convention Center. It contains a exhibit hall, a grand ballroom, and sixteen meeting rooms.
The city has hosts the <a href="Greater%20Gulf%20State%20Fair">Greater Gulf State Fair</a>, held each October since 1955. The city also hosted <a href="Bayfest%20%28Mobile%29">BayFest</a>, an annual three-day music festival with more than 125 live musical acts on multiple stages spread throughout downtown; it now holds Ten Sixty Five festival, a free music festival.
The Mobile Theatre Guild is a nonprofit <a href="community%20theatre">community theatre</a> that has served the city since 1947. It is a member of the <a href="Mobile%20Arts%20Council">Mobile Arts Council</a>, the Alabama Conference of Theatre and Speech, the Southeastern Theatre Conference, and the American Association of Community Theatres. Mobile is also host to the Joe Jefferson Players, Alabama's oldest continually running community theatre. The group was named in honor of the famous comedic actor <a href="Joseph%20Jefferson">Joe Jefferson</a>, who spend part of his teenage years in Mobile. The Players debuted their first production on December 17, 1947. Drama Camp Productions and Sunny Side Theater is Mobile's home for children's theater and fun. The group began doing summer camps in 2002, expanded to a year-round facility in 2008 and recently moved into the Azalea City Center for the Arts, a community of drama, music, art, photography, and dance teachers. The group has produced Broadway shows including "Miracle on 34th Street", "Honk", "Fame", and "Hairspray".
The <a href="Mobile%20Arts%20Council">Mobile Arts Council</a> is an umbrella organization for the arts in Mobile. It was founded in 1955 as a project of the Junior League of Mobile with the mission to increase cooperation among artistic and cultural organizations in the area and to provide a forum for problems in art, music, theater, and literature.
Tourism.
Museums.
Mobile is home to a variety of museums. <a href="Battleship%20Memorial%20Park">Battleship Memorial Park</a> is a military park on the shore of Mobile Bay and features the World War II era <a href="battleship">battleship</a> , the World War II era <a href="submarine">submarine</a> , <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a> and <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a> Memorials, and a variety of historical military equipment. The <a href="Old%20City%20Hall%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">History Museum of Mobile</a> showcases 300 plus years of Mobile history and prehistory. It is housed in the historic <a href="Old%20City%20Hall%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Old City Hall</a> (1857), a National Historic Landmark. The <a href="Oakleigh%20Historic%20Complex%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Oakleigh Historic Complex</a> features three house museums that attempt to interpret the lives of people from three strata of 19th century society in Mobile, that of the enslaved, the working class, and the upper class. The <a href="Mobile%20Carnival%20Museum">Mobile Carnival Museum</a>, housing the city's <a href="Mardi%20Gras%20in%20Mobile">Mardi Gras</a> history and memorabilia, documents the variety of floats, costumes, and displays seen during the history of the festival season. The <a href="Bragg-Mitchell%20Mansion">Bragg-Mitchell Mansion</a> (1855), <a href="Richards%20DAR%20House">Richards DAR House</a> (1860), and the <a href="Conde-Charlotte%20House">Condé-Charlotte House</a> (1822) are historic, furnished <a href="antebellum%20architecture">antebellum</a> house museums. <a href="Fort%20Morgan%20%28Alabama%29">Fort Morgan</a> (1819), <a href="Fort%20Gaines%20%28Alabama%29">Fort Gaines</a> (1821), and <a href="Blakeley%2C%20Alabama">Historic Blakeley State Park</a> all figure predominantly in local <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a> history.
The Mobile Medical Museum is housed in the historic French colonial-style Vincent-Doan House (1827). It features artifacts and resources that chronicle the long history of medicine in Mobile. The Phoenix Fire Museum is located in the restored Phoenix Volunteer Fire Company Number 6 building and features the history of fire companies in Mobile from their organization in 1838. The Mobile Police Department Museum features exhibits that chronicle the history of law enforcement in Mobile. The <a href="Gulf%20Coast%20Exploreum%20Science%20Center">Gulf Coast Exploreum Science Center</a> is a non-profit science center located in downtown. It features permanent and traveling exhibits, an <a href="IMAX">IMAX</a> dome theater, a digital 3D virtual theater, and a hands-on chemistry laboratory. The <a href="Dauphin%20Island%20Sea%20Lab">Dauphin Island Sea Lab</a> is located south of the city, on Dauphin Island near the mouth of <a href="Mobile%20Bay">Mobile Bay</a>. It houses the Estuarium, an aquarium which illustrates the four habitats of the <a href="Mobile%20Bay">Mobile Bay</a> <a href="ecosystem">ecosystem</a>: the <a href="Mobile%20River">river delta</a>, <a href="Mobile%20Bay">bay</a>, <a href="Dauphin%20Island">barrier islands</a> and <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>.
Parks and other attractions.
The <a href="Mobile%20Botanical%20Gardens">Mobile Botanical Gardens</a> feature a variety of flora spread over . It contains the Millie McConnell <a href="Rhododendron">Rhododendron</a> Garden with 1,000 evergreen and native azaleas and the <a href="Longleaf%20Pine">Longleaf Pine</a> Habitat. <a href="Bellingrath%20Gardens%20and%20Home">Bellingrath Gardens and Home</a>, located on <a href="Fowl%20River">Fowl River</a>, is a <a href="botanical%20garden">botanical garden</a> and historic mansion that dates to the 1930s. The 5 Rivers Delta Resource Center is a facility that allows visitors to learn about and access the <a href="Mobile%20River">Mobile</a>, <a href="Tensaw%20River">Tensaw</a>, <a href="Apalachee%20River%20%28Alabama%29">Apalachee</a>, <a href="Middle%20River%20%28Alabama%29">Middle</a>, <a href="Blakeley%20River">Blakeley</a>, and <a href="Spanish%20River%20%28Alabama%29">Spanish</a> rivers. It was established to serve as an easily accessible gateway to the <a href="Mobile-Tensaw%20River%20Delta">Mobile-Tensaw River Delta</a>. In addition to offering several boat and adventure tours, it contains a small theater; exhibit hall; meeting facilities; walking trails; a canoe and kayak landing.
Mobile has more than 45 public parks within its limits, with some that are of special note. <a href="Bienville%20Square">Bienville Square</a> is a historic park in the Lower Dauphin Street Historic District. It assumed its current form in 1850 and is named for Mobile's founder, Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville. It was once the principal gathering place for residents, when the city was smaller, and remains popular today. <a href="Cathedral%20Square%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Cathedral Square</a> is a one-block performing arts park, also in the Lower Dauphin Street Historic District, which is overlooked by the <a href="Cathedral%20Basilica%20of%20the%20Immaculate%20Conception%2C%20Mobile">Cathedral Basilica of the Immaculate Conception</a>.
The Fort of Colonial Mobile is a reconstruction of the city's original Fort Condé, built on the original fort's footprint. It serves as the official welcome center and a colonial-era living history museum. Spanish Plaza is a downtown park that honors the Spanish phase of the city between 1780 and 1813. It features the "Arches of Friendship", a fountain presented to Mobile by the city of <a href="M%C3%A1laga">Málaga</a>, Spain. <a href="Langan%20%28Municipal%29%20Park">Langan Park</a>, the largest of the parks at , features lakes, natural spaces, and contains the <a href="Mobile%20Museum%20of%20Art">Mobile Museum of Art</a>, Azalea City Golf Course, <a href="Mobile%20Botanical%20Gardens">Mobile Botanical Gardens</a> and Playhouse in the Park.
Historic architecture.
Mobile has antebellum architectural examples of <a href="Greek%20Revival%20architecture">Greek Revival</a>, <a href="Gothic%20Revival">Gothic Revival</a>, <a href="Italianate%20architecture">Italianate</a>, and <a href="Creole%20cottage">Creole cottage</a>. Later architectural styles found in the city include the various <a href="Victorian%20architecture">Victorian</a> types, <a href="Shotgun%20house">shotgun</a> types, <a href="Colonial%20Revival%20architecture">Colonial Revival</a>, <a href="Tudor%20Revival%20architecture">Tudor Revival</a>, <a href="Spanish%20Colonial%20Revival%20architecture">Spanish Colonial Revival</a>, <a href="Beaux-Arts%20architecture">Beaux-Arts</a> and many others. The city currently has nine major <a href="Historic%20districts%20in%20the%20United%20States">historic districts</a>: <a href="Old%20Dauphin%20Way%20Historic%20District">Old Dauphin Way</a>, <a href="Oakleigh%20Garden%20Historic%20District">Oakleigh Garden</a>, <a href="Lower%20Dauphin%20Street%20Historic%20District">Lower Dauphin Street</a>, <a href="Leinkauf%20Historic%20District">Leinkauf</a>, <a href="De%20Tonti%20Square%20Historic%20District">De Tonti Square</a>, <a href="Church%20Street%20East%20Historic%20District">Church Street East</a>, <a href="Ashland%20Place%20Historic%20District%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Ashland Place</a>, <a href="Campground%20Historic%20District">Campground</a>, and <a href="Midtown%20Historic%20District%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Midtown</a>.
Mobile has a number of historic structures in the city, including numerous churches and private homes. Mobile's historic churches include <a href="Christ%20Church%20Cathedral%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Christ Church Cathedral</a>, the <a href="Cathedral%20Basilica%20of%20the%20Immaculate%20Conception%2C%20Mobile">Cathedral Basilica of the Immaculate Conception</a>, <a href="Emanuel%20AME%20Church%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Emanuel AME Church</a>, <a href="Government%20Street%20Presbyterian%20Church">Government Street Presbyterian Church</a>, <a href="St.%20Louis%20Street%20Missionary%20Baptist%20Church">St. Louis Street Missionary Baptist Church</a>, <a href="State%20Street%20AME%20Zion%20Church">State Street AME Zion Church</a>, <a href="Stone%20Street%20Baptist%20Church">Stone Street Baptist Church</a>, <a href="Trinity%20Episcopal%20Church%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Trinity Episcopal Church</a>, <a href="St.%20Francis%20Street%20Methodist%20Church">St. Francis Street Methodist Church</a>, <a href="Saint%20Joseph%27s%20Roman%20Catholic%20Church%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Saint Joseph's Roman Catholic Church</a>, <a href="Saint%20Francis%20Xavier%20Roman%20Catholic%20Church%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Saint Francis Xavier Catholic Church</a>, <a href="Saint%20Matthew%27s%20Catholic%20Church%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Saint Matthew's Catholic Church</a>, <a href="Saint%20Paul%27s%20Episcopal%20Chapel%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Saint Paul's Episcopal Chapel</a>, and <a href="Saint%20Vincent%20de%20Paul%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Saint Vincent de Paul</a>. The <a href="Sodality%20Chapel">Sodality Chapel</a> and <a href="Spring%20Hill%20College%20Quadrangle">St. Joseph's Chapel</a> at Spring Hill College are two historic churches on that campus. Two historic Roman Catholic convents survive, the <a href="Convent%20and%20Academy%20of%20the%20Visitation">Convent and Academy of the Visitation</a> and the <a href="Convent%20of%20Mercy%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Convent of Mercy</a>.
<a href="Barton%20Academy">Barton Academy</a> is a historic Greek Revival school building and local landmark on Government Street. The <a href="Bishop%20Portier%20House">Bishop Portier House</a> and the <a href="Carlen%20House">Carlen House</a> are two of the many surviving examples of <a href="Creole%20cottage">Creole cottage</a>s in the city. The <a href="Mobile%20City%20Hospital">Mobile City Hospital</a> and the <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Hospital%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">United States Marine Hospital</a> are both restored <a href="Greek%20Revival%20architecture">Greek Revival</a> hospital buildings that predate the Civil War. The <a href="Washington%20Firehouse%20No.%205">Washington Firehouse No. 5</a> is a Greek Revival fire station, built in 1851. The <a href="Hunter%20House%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Hunter House</a> is an example of the <a href="Italianate%20architecture">Italianate</a> style and was built by a successful 19th-century African American businesswoman. The <a href="Monterey%20Place">Shepard House</a> is a good example of the <a href="Queen%20Anne%20style%20architecture%20in%20the%20United%20States">Queen Anne</a> style. The <a href="Scottish%20Rite%20Temple%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Scottish Rite Temple</a> is the only surviving example of <a href="Egyptian%20Revival%20architecture">Egyptian Revival architecture</a> in the city. The <a href="Gulf%2C%20Mobile%20and%20Ohio%20Passenger%20Terminal">Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Passenger Terminal</a> is an example of the <a href="Mission%20Revival%20Style%20architecture">Mission Revival</a> style.
The city has several historic cemeteries that were established shortly after the colonial era. They replaced the colonial <a href="Cemetery">Campo Santo</a>, of which no trace remains. The <a href="Church%20Street%20Graveyard">Church Street Graveyard</a> contains above-ground tombs and monuments spread over and was founded in 1819, during the height of <a href="yellow%20fever">yellow fever</a> epidemics. The nearby <a href="Magnolia%20Cemetery%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Magnolia Cemetery</a> was established in 1836 and served as Mobile's primary burial site during the 19th and early 20th centuries, with approximately 80,000 burials. It features tombs and many intricately carved monuments and statues.
The <a href="Catholic%20Cemetery%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Catholic Cemetery</a> was established in 1848 by the <a href="Archdiocese%20of%20Mobile">Archdiocese of Mobile</a> and covers more than . It contains plots for the <a href="Brothers%20of%20the%20Sacred%20Heart">Brothers of the Sacred Heart</a>, <a href="Little%20Sisters%20of%20the%20Poor">Little Sisters of the Poor</a>, <a href="Sisters%20of%20Charity">Sisters of Charity</a>, and <a href="Sisters%20of%20Mercy">Sisters of Mercy</a>, in addition to many other historically significant burials. Mobile's <a href="Congregation%20Sha%27arai%20Shomayim%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Jewish</a> community dates back to the 1820s and the city has two historic <a href="Jewish%20cemetery">Jewish cemeteries</a>, <a href="Sha%27arai%20Shomayim%20Cemetery">Sha'arai Shomayim Cemetery</a> and <a href="Ahavas%20Chesed%20Cemetery">Ahavas Chesed Cemetery</a>. Sha'arai Shomayim is the older of the two.
Demographics.
2020 census.
As of the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20census">2020 United States census</a>, there were 187,041 people, 77,628 households, and 41,260 families residing in the city.
2010 census.
The 2010 United States Census determined that there were 195,111 people residing within the city limits of Mobile. Mobile is the center of <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a>'s second-largest metropolitan area, which consists of all of Mobile County. <a href="Mobile%20metropolitan%20area">Metropolitan Mobile</a> is estimated to have a population of 413,936 in 2012.
The 2010 census indicated that there were 78,959 households, out of which 21,073 had children under the age of 18 living with them, 28,073 were married couples living together, 17,037 had a female householder with no husband present, 3,579 had a male householder with no wife present, and 30,270 were non-families. 25,439 of all households were made up of individuals, and 8,477 had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The racial makeup of the city was 50.6% <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">Black</a> or <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">African American</a>, 45.0% <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.3% <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 1.8% <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.0% <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 0.9% from <a href="Race%20%28US%20Census%29">other races</a>, 1.4% from two or more races, and 2.4% of the population were Latino. <a href="Non-Hispanic%20Whites">Non-Hispanic Whites</a> were 43.9% of the population in 2010, down from 62.1% in 1980. The average household size was 2.4 and the average family size was 3.07. Estimated same-sex couple households comprised 0.3% of all households in 2010.
The age distribution of the population in 2010 consisted of 6.7% under the age of five years, 75.9% over 18, and 13.7% over 65. The median age was 35.7 years. The male population was 47.0% and the female population was 53.0%. The median income for a household in the city was $37,056 for 2006 to 2010. The per capita income for the city was $22,401.
Government.
Since 1985 the government of Mobile has consisted of a mayor and a seven-member <a href="city%20council">city council</a>. The mayor is elected <a href="at-large">at-large</a>, and the council members are elected from each of the seven city council <a href="single-member%20districts">single-member districts</a> (SMDs). A <a href="supermajority">supermajority</a> of five votes is required to conduct council business.
This form of city government was chosen by the voters after the previous form of government, which had three city commissioners, each elected at-large, was ruled in 1975 to substantially dilute the minority vote and violate the <a href="Voting%20Rights%20Act">Voting Rights Act</a> in "<a href="Mobile%20v.%20Bolden">Bolden v. City of Mobile</a>". The three at-large commissioners each required a majority vote to win. Due to appeals, the case took time to reach settlement and establishment of a new electoral system. Municipal elections are held every four years and are nonpartisan.
The first mayor elected under the new system of <a href="single-member%20district">single-member district</a> (SMD) voting was <a href="Arthur%20R.%20Outlaw">Arthur R. Outlaw</a>, who served his second term as mayor from 1985 to 1989. His first term had been under the old system, from 1967 to 1968. <a href="Mike%20Dow">Mike Dow</a> defeated Outlaw in the 1989 election; he was re-elected, serving as mayor for four terms, from 1989 to 2005. His "The String of Pearls" initiative, a series of projects designed to stimulate redevelopment of the city's core, is credited with reviving much of downtown Mobile. Upon his retirement, Dow endorsed <a href="Sam%20Jones%20%28mayor%29">Sam Jones</a> as his successor.
Sam Jones was elected in 2005 as the first African-American mayor of Mobile. He was re-elected for a second term in 2009 without opposition. His administration continued the focus on downtown redevelopment and bringing industries to the city. He ran for a third term in 2013 but was defeated by <a href="Sandy%20Stimpson">Sandy Stimpson</a>. Stimpson took office on November 4, 2013, and was re-elected on August 22, 2017.
As of January 2022, the seven-member city council is made up of Cory Penn from District 1, William Carroll from District 2, C.J. Small from District 3, Ben Reynolds from District 4, Joel Daves from District 5, Scott Jones from District 6, and Gina Gregory from District 7.
Education.
Public facilities.
Public schools in Mobile are operated by the <a href="Mobile%20County%20Public%20School%20System">Mobile County Public School System</a>. The Mobile County Public School System has an enrollment of approximately 55,200 students at 88 schools, employs approximately 7,026 public school employees, and had a budget in 2020-2021 of $623 million. The State of Alabama operates the <a href="Alabama%20School%20of%20Mathematics%20and%20Science">Alabama School of Mathematics and Science</a> on Dauphin Street in Mobile, which boards advanced Alabama high school students. It was founded in 1989 to identify, challenge, and educate future leaders.
Private facilities.
Mobile also has a large number of private schools, most of them <a href="Parochial%20school">parochial</a> in nature. Many belong to the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Mobile">Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mobile</a>. The private Catholic institutions include <a href="McGill-Toolen%20Catholic%20High%20School">McGill-Toolen Catholic High School</a> (1896), Corpus Christi School, Little Flower Catholic School (1934), Most Pure Heart of Mary Catholic School (1900), Saint Dominic School (1961), Saint Ignatius School (1952), Saint Mary Catholic School (1867), Saint Pius X Catholic School (1957), and Saint Vincent DePaul Catholic School (1976).
Notable private Protestant institutions include <a href="St.%20Paul%27s%20Episcopal%20School">St. Paul's Episcopal School</a> (1947), Mobile Christian School (1961), St. Lukes Episcopal School (1961), Cottage Hill Baptist School System (1961), <a href="Faith%20Academy%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Faith Academy</a> (1967), and Trinity Lutheran School (1955).
<a href="UMS-Wright%20Preparatory%20School">UMS-Wright Preparatory School</a> is an independent co-educational <a href="university-preparatory%20school">preparatory school</a>. It assumed its current configuration in 1988, when the University Military School (founded 1893) and the Julius T. Wright School for Girls (1923) merged to form UMS-Wright.
Primary and secondary.
Major colleges and universities in Mobile that are accredited by the <a href="Southern%20Association%20of%20Colleges%20and%20Schools">Southern Association of Colleges and Schools</a> include the University of South Alabama, Spring Hill College, the University of Mobile, Faulkner University, and Bishop State Community College.
Undergraduate and postgraduate.
The <a href="University%20of%20South%20Alabama">University of South Alabama</a> is a public, <a href="Doctorate">doctoral</a>-level university established in 1963. The university is composed of the College of Arts and Sciences, the Mitchell College of Business, the College of Education, the College of Engineering, the College of Medicine, the Doctor of Pharmacy Program, the College of Nursing, the School of Computing, and the School of Continuing Education and Special Programs.
<a href="Faulkner%20University">Faulkner University</a> is a four-year private <a href="Churches%20of%20Christ">Church of Christ</a>-affiliated university based in <a href="Montgomery%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery, Alabama</a>. The Mobile campus was established in 1975 and offers bachelor's degrees in Business Administration, Management of Human Resources, and Criminal Justice. It also offers associate degrees in Business Administration, Business Information Systems, Computer & Information Science, Criminal Justice, Informatics, Legal Studies, Arts, and Science.
<a href="Spring%20Hill%20College">Spring Hill College</a>, chartered in 1830, was the first Catholic college in the southeastern United States and is the third oldest <a href="Society%20of%20Jesus">Jesuit</a> college in the country. This four-year private college offers graduate programs in Business Administration, Education, Liberal Arts, Nursing (MSN), and Theological Studies. Undergraduate divisions and programs include the Division of Business, the Communications/Arts Division, International Studies, Inter-divisional Studies, the Language and Literature Division, Bachelor of Science in Nursing, Philosophy and Theology, Political Science, the Sciences Division, the Social Sciences Division, and the Teacher Education Division.
The <a href="University%20of%20Mobile">University of Mobile</a> is a four-year private Baptist-affiliated university in the neighboring city of Prichard that was founded in 1961. It consists of the College of Arts and Sciences, School of Business, School of Christian Studies, School of Education, the School of Leadership Development, and the School of Nursing.
Community college.
<a href="Bishop%20State%20Community%20College">Bishop State Community College</a>, founded in 1927, is a public, <a href="Historically%20black%20colleges%20and%20universities">historically African American</a>, <a href="Community%20colleges%20in%20the%20United%20States">community college</a>. Bishop State has four campuses in Mobile and offers a wide array of <a href="associate%20degree">associate degree</a>s.
Vocational.
Several post-secondary, <a href="Vocational%20education">vocational</a>-type institutions have a campus in Mobile. These include the Alabama Institute Of Real Estate, American Academy Of Hypnosis, Bealle School Of Real Estate, Charles Academy Of Beauty Culture, <a href="Fortis%20College">Fortis College</a>, <a href="Virginia%20College">Virginia College</a>, <a href="ITT%20Technical%20Institute">ITT Technical Institute</a>, <a href="Remington%20College">Remington College</a> and White And Sons Barber College.
Healthcare.
Mobile serves the central Gulf Coast as a regional center for medicine, with over 850 physicians and 175 dentists. There are four major medical centers within the city limits.
Mobile Infirmary Medical Center has 704 beds and is the largest nonprofit hospital in the state. It was founded in 1910. <a href="Providence%20Hospital%20%28Mobile%29">Providence Hospital</a> has 349 beds. It was founded in 1854 by the <a href="Daughters%20of%20Charity%20of%20Saint%20Vincent%20de%20Paul">Daughters of Charity</a> from <a href="Emmitsburg%2C%20Maryland">Emmitsburg, Maryland</a>. The University of South Alabama Medical Center has 346 beds. Its roots go back to 1830 with the old city-owned <a href="Mobile%20City%20Hospital">Mobile City Hospital</a> and associated medical school. A teaching hospital, it is designated as Mobile's only <a href="level%20I%20trauma%20center">level I trauma center</a> by the <a href="Alabama%20Department%20of%20Public%20Health">Alabama Department of Public Health</a>. It is also a regional burn center. Springhill Medical Center, with 252 beds, was founded in 1975. It is Mobile's only for-profit facility.
Additionally, the University of South Alabama operates the University of South Alabama Children's and Women's Hospital with 219 beds, dedicated exclusively to the care of women and minors. In 2008, the University of South Alabama opened the USA Mitchell Cancer Center Institute. The center is home to the first academic cancer research center in the central Gulf Coast region.
Mobile Infirmary Medical Center operated Infirmary West, formerly Knollwood Hospital, with 100 acute-care beds, but closed the facility at the end of October 2012 due to declining revenues.
BayPointe Hospital and Children's Residential Services, with 94-beds, is the only psychiatric hospital in the city. It houses a residential unit for children, an acute unit for children and adolescents, and an age-segregated involuntary hospital unit for adults undergoing evaluation ordered by the Mobile Probate Court.
The city has a broad array of outpatient surgical centers, emergency clinics, home health care services, assisted-living facilities and <a href="Nursing%20home">skilled nursing facilities</a>.
Economy.
Aerospace, steel, ship building, retail, services, construction, medicine, and manufacturing are Mobile's major industries. After having economic decline for several decades, Mobile's economy began to rebound in the late 1980s. Between 1993 and 2003 roughly 13,983 new jobs were created as 87 new companies were founded and 399 existing companies were expanded.
Defunct companies that had been founded or based in Mobile included <a href="Alabama%20Drydock%20and%20Shipbuilding%20Company">Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company</a>, <a href="Delchamps">Delchamps</a>, and <a href="Gayfers">Gayfers</a>. Current companies that were formerly based in the city include <a href="Checkers%20%28fast%20food%29">Checkers</a>, <a href="Konica%20Minolta">Minolta-QMS</a>, <a href="Morrison%20Management%20Specialists">Morrison's</a>, and the <a href="Waterman%20Steamship%20Corporation">Waterman Steamship Corporation</a>.
In addition to those discussed below, AlwaysHD, <a href="Foosackly%27s">Foosackly's</a>, <a href="Integrity%20Media">Integrity Media</a>, and <a href="Volkert%2C%20Inc.">Volkert, Inc.</a> are headquartered in Mobile.
Major industry.
Port of Mobile.
Mobile's <a href="Port%20of%20Mobile">Alabama State Docks</a> underwent the largest expansion in its history in the early 21st century. It expanded its container processing and storage facility and increased container storage at the docks by over 1,000% at a cost of over $300 million, a project completed in 2005. Despite the expansion of its container capabilities and the addition of two massive new cranes, the port went from 9th largest to the 12th largest by tonnage in the nation from 2008 to 2010.
Shipyards.
Shipbuilding began to make a major comeback in Mobile in 1999 with the founding of <a href="Austal%20USA">Austal USA</a>. A subsidiary of the Australian company <a href="Austal">Austal</a>, it expanded its production facility for United States defense and commercial aluminum shipbuilding on <a href="Blakeley%20Island%20%28Alabama%29">Blakeley Island</a> in 2005. Austal announced in October 2012, after winning a new defense contract and completing another building within their complex on the island, that it would expand its workforce from 3,000 to 4,500 employees.
<a href="Atlantic%20Marine">Atlantic Marine</a> operated a major shipyard at the former Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company site on <a href="Pinto%20Island">Pinto Island</a>. It was acquired by British defense conglomerate <a href="BAE%20Systems">BAE Systems</a> in May 2010 for $352 million. Doing business as <a href="BAE%20Systems%20Southeast%20Shipyards">BAE Systems Southeast Shipyards</a>, the company continues to operate the site as a full-service shipyard, employing approximately 600 workers with plans to expand.
Mobile Aeroplex at Brookley.
The <a href="Mobile%20Aeroplex%20at%20Brookley">Mobile Aeroplex at Brookley</a> is an industrial complex and airport located south of the central business district of the city. It is the largest industrial and transportation complex in the region, having more than 70 companies, many of which are <a href="aerospace">aerospace</a>, spread over . Notable employers at Brookley include <a href="Airbus">Airbus</a> North America Engineering (<a href="EADS%20North%20America">Airbus Military North America</a>'s facilities are at the Mobile Regional Airport), <a href="ST%20Aerospace%20Mobile">ST Aerospace Mobile</a> (a division of <a href="ST%20Engineering">ST Engineering</a>), and <a href="Continental%20Motors%2C%20Inc.">Continental Motors</a>.
Plans for an <a href="Airbus%20A320%20family">Airbus A320 family</a> aircraft assembly plant in Mobile were formally announced by <a href="Airbus">Airbus</a> CEO <a href="Fabrice%20Br%C3%A9gier">Fabrice Brégier</a> from the Mobile Convention Center on July 2, 2012. The plans include a $600 million factory at the Brookley Aeroplex for the assembly of the A319, A320 and A321 aircraft. It was planned to employ up roughly 1,000 full-time workers when fully operational. Construction began with a groundbreaking ceremony on April 8, 2013, with it becoming operable by 2015 and producing up to 50 aircraft per year by 2017. The assembly plant is the company's first factory to be built within the United States. It was announced on February 1, 2013, that Airbus had hired Alabama-based <a href="Hoar%20Construction">Hoar Construction</a> to oversee construction of the facility.
The factory officially opened on September 14, 2015, covering one million square feet on 53 acres of flat grassland.
On October 16, 2017, Airbus announced a partnership with <a href="Bombardier%20Aerospace">Bombardier Aerospace</a>, taking over a majority share of the <a href="Bombardier%20CSeries">Bombardier CSeries</a> airliner program. As a result of this partnership, Airbus plans to open an assembly line for CSeries aircraft in Mobile, particularly to serve the US market. This effort may allow the companies to circumvent high import tariffs on the CSeries family. The aircraft was renamed the Airbus A220 on July 10, 2018. Production started in August 2019; the first A220 from the new line is due to be delivered to Delta in the third quarter of 2020.
ThyssenKrupp.
German technology conglomerate <a href="ThyssenKrupp">ThyssenKrupp</a> broke ground on a $4.65 billion combined <a href="stainless%20steel">stainless</a> and <a href="carbon%20steel">carbon steel</a> processing facility in Calvert, a few miles north of Mobile, in 2007. It was originally projected to eventually employ 2,700 people. The facility became operational in July 2010.
The company put both its carbon mill in Calvert and a steel slab-making unit in <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> up for sale in May 2012, citing rising production costs and a worldwide decrease in demand. ThyssenKrupp's stainless steel division, Inoxum, including the stainless portion of the Calvert plant, was sold to Finnish stainless steel company <a href="Outokumpu">Outokumpu Oyi</a> in 2012.
