Transportation.
Air.
Local airline passengers are served by the <a href="Mobile%20Regional%20Airport">Mobile Regional Airport</a>, with direct connections to four major hub airports. It is served by <a href="American%20Eagle%20%28airline%20brand%29">American Eagle</a>, with service to <a href="Dallas/Fort%20Worth%20International%20Airport">Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport</a> and <a href="Charlotte/Douglas%20International%20Airport">Charlotte/Douglas International Airport</a>; <a href="United%20Express">United Express</a>, with service to <a href="George%20Bush%20Intercontinental%20Airport">George Bush Intercontinental Airport</a> and <a href="Delta%20Connection">Delta Connection</a>, with service to <a href="Hartsfield-Jackson%20International%20Airport">Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport</a>. The <a href="Mobile%20Downtown%20Airport">Mobile Downtown Airport</a> at the <a href="Mobile%20Aeroplex%20at%20Brookley">Brookley Aeroplex</a> serves corporate, cargo, and private aircraft.
Cycling paths.
In an effort to leverage Mobile's waterways for recreational use, as opposed to simply industrial use, The Three Mile Creek Greenway Trail is being designed and implemented under the instruction of the City Council. The linear park will ultimately span seven miles, from <a href="Langan%20%28Municipal%29%20Park">Langan (Municipal) Park</a> to Dr. Martin Luther King Junior Avenue, and include trailheads, sidewalks, and bike lanes. The existing greenway is centered at Tricentennial Park.
Other trails include the paved Mobile Airport Perimeter Trail, encircling the <a href="Mobile%20Downtown%20Airport">Mobile Downtown Airport</a> and mountain biking trails on the west side of the <a href="University%20of%20South%20Alabama">University of South Alabama</a>.
Rail.
Mobile is served by four <a href="Class%20I%20railroad">Class I railroad</a>s, including the <a href="Canadian%20National%20Railway">Canadian National Railway</a> (CNR), <a href="CSX%20Transportation">CSX Transportation</a> (CSX), the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Southern%20Railway">Kansas City Southern Railway</a> (KCS), and the <a href="Norfolk%20Southern%20Railway">Norfolk Southern Railway</a> (NS). The <a href="Alabama%20and%20Gulf%20Coast%20Railway">Alabama and Gulf Coast Railway</a> (AGR), a <a href="Class%20III%20railroad">Class III railroad</a>, links Mobile to the <a href="BNSF%20Railway">Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway</a> (BNSF) at <a href="Amory%2C%20Mississippi">Amory, Mississippi</a>. These converge at the Port of Mobile, which provides <a href="intermodal%20freight%20transport">intermodal freight transport</a> service to companies engaged in importing and exporting. Other railroads include the <a href="CG%20Railway">CG Railway</a> (CGR), a rail ship service to <a href="Coatzacoalcos">Coatzacoalcos</a>, <a href="Veracruz">Veracruz</a>, and the <a href="Terminal%20Railway%20Alabama%20State%20Docks">Terminal Railway Alabama State Docks</a> (TASD), a <a href="Switching%20and%20terminal%20railroad">switching railroad</a>.
The city was served by <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>'s "<a href="Sunset%20Limited">Sunset Limited</a>" passenger train service until 2005, when the service was suspended due to the effects of <a href="Hurricane%20Katrina">Hurricane Katrina</a>. However, efforts to restart passenger rail service between Mobile and <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> were revived in 2019 by the 21-member Southern Rail Commission after receiving a $33 million Federal Railroad Administration grant in June of that year. Louisiana quickly dedicated its $10 million toward the project, and Mississippi initially balked before committing its $15 million sum but Governor <a href="Kay%20Ivey">Kay Ivey</a> resisted committing the estimated $2.7 million state allocation from Alabama because of concerns regarding long-term financial commitments and potential competition with freight traffic from the <a href="Port%20of%20Mobile">Port of Mobile</a> The Winter of 2019 was marked by repeated postponement of votes by the Mobile City Council as it requested more information on how rail traffic from the port would be impacted and where the Amtrak station would be built as community support for the project became more vocal, especially among <a href="millennials">millennials</a>. A day before a deadline in the federal grant matching program being used to fund the project, the city council committed about $3 million in a 6–1 vote. About $2.2 million is still needed for infrastructure improvements and train station must still be built before service begins in 2023. Potential locations for the station include at the foot of <a href="Government%20Street%20%28Mobile%2C%20Alabama%29">Government Street</a> in downtown and in the <a href="Mobile%20Aeroplex%20at%20Brookley">Mobile Aeroplex at Brookley</a>, which is favored by the <a href="Port%20of%20Mobile">Port of Mobile</a>
Roadways.
Two major <a href="interstate%20highways">interstate highways</a> and a spur converge in Mobile. <a href="Interstate%2010">Interstate 10</a> runs northeast to southwest across the city while <a href="Interstate%2065">Interstate 65</a> starts in Mobile at Interstate 10 and runs north. <a href="Interstate%20165%20%28Alabama%29">Interstate 165</a> connects to Interstate 65 north of the city in <a href="Prichard%2C%20Alabama">Prichard</a> and joins Interstate 10 in downtown Mobile. Mobile is well served by many major highway systems. United States Highways <a href="U.S.%20Route%2031%20in%20Alabama">US 31</a>, <a href="US%2043%20%28AL%29">US 43</a>, <a href="US%2045%20%28AL%29">US 45</a>, <a href="US%2090%20%28AL%29">US 90</a>, and <a href="US%2098%20%28AL%29">US 98</a> radiate from Mobile traveling east, west, and north. Mobile has three routes east across the Mobile River and Mobile Bay into neighboring <a href="Baldwin%20County%2C%20Alabama">Baldwin County, Alabama</a>. Interstate 10 leaves downtown through the <a href="George%20Wallace%20Tunnel">George Wallace Tunnel</a> under the river and then over the bay across the <a href="Jubilee%20Parkway">Jubilee Parkway</a> to <a href="Spanish%20Fort%2C%20Alabama">Spanish Fort</a> and <a href="Daphne%2C%20Alabama">Daphne</a>. US 98 leaves downtown through the <a href="Bankhead%20Tunnel">Bankhead Tunnel</a> under the river, onto <a href="Blakeley%20Island%20%28Alabama%29">Blakeley Island</a>, and then over the bay across the <a href="Battleship%20Parkway">Battleship Parkway</a> into Spanish Fort, Alabama. US 90 travels over the <a href="Cochrane%E2%80%93Africatown%20USA%20Bridge">Cochrane–Africatown USA Bridge</a> to the north of downtown onto Blakeley Island where it becomes co-routed with US 98.
Mobile's public transportation is the <a href="The%20Wave%20Transit%20System">Wave Transit System</a> which features buses with 18 fixed routes and neighborhood service. Baylinc is a public transportation bus service provided by the Baldwin Rural Transit System in cooperation with the Wave Transit System that provides service between eastern <a href="Baldwin%20County%2C%20Alabama">Baldwin County</a> and downtown Mobile. Baylinc operates Monday through Friday.
<a href="Greyhound%20Lines">Greyhound Lines</a> provides intercity bus service between Mobile and many locations throughout the United States. Mobile is served by several taxi and limousine services.
Water.
The <a href="Port%20of%20Mobile">Port of Mobile</a> has public, deepwater terminals with direct access to of inland and intracoastal waterways serving the <a href="Great%20Lakes">Great Lakes</a>, the <a href="Ohio%20River">Ohio</a> and <a href="Tennessee%20River">Tennessee river</a> valleys (via the <a href="Tennessee-Tombigbee%20Waterway">Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway</a>), and the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a>. The Alabama State Port Authority owns and operates the public terminals at the Port of Mobile. The public terminals handle <a href="Containerization">containerized</a>, bulk, breakbulk, <a href="roll-on/roll-off">roll-on/roll-off</a>, and heavy-lift cargoes. The port is also home to private bulk terminal operators, as well as a number of highly specialized shipbuilding and repair companies with two of the largest floating dry docks on the Gulf Coast.
The city was a home port for <a href="cruise%20ship">cruise ship</a>s from <a href="Carnival%20Cruise%20Lines">Carnival Cruise Lines</a>. The first cruise ship to call the port home was the "<a href="Holiday%20%28ship%29">Holiday</a>", which left the city in November 2009 so that a larger and newer ship could take its place. The "<a href="Carnival%20Fantasy">Carnival Fantasy</a>" operated from Mobile from then on until the "<a href="Carnival%20Elation">Carnival Elation</a>" arrived in May 2010. In early 2011, Carnival announced that despite fully booked cruises, the company would cease operations from Mobile in October 2011. This cessation of cruise service left the city with an annual <a href="interest">debt service</a> of around two million dollars related to the terminal. In September 2015, Carnival announced that the "<a href="Carnival%20Fantasy">Carnival Fantasy</a>" was relocating from Miami, Florida to Mobile, Alabama after a five-year absence and would offer four and five night cruises to Mexico that started in November 2016 through November 2017. The four night cruises will visit Cozumel, Mexico while the five night cruises will additionally visit Costa Maya or Progreso. Her first departure from Mobile left on November 9, 2016, on a five night cruise to Cozumel and Progreso. "<a href="Carnival%20Fascination">Carnival Fascination</a>" will be replacing "Carnival Fantasy" in 2022.
Although Carnival Cruise Lines did not operate from Mobile after the Carnival Fantasy left in 2011, the "<a href="Carnival%20Triumph">Carnival Triumph</a>" was towed into the port following a crippling engine room fire. It was the largest cruise ship ever to dock at the cruise terminal in Mobile. Later it was eclipsed by the "<a href="Carnival%20Conquest">Carnival Conquest</a>", which docked in Mobile when the <a href="Port%20of%20New%20Orleans">Port of New Orleans</a> was temporarily closed. Larger commercial ships routinely arrive at the Port of Mobile.

Radio.
In total, 55 radio stations are located around the Mobile area and provide signals sufficiently strong to serve Mobile.
Fourteen <a href="FM%20broadcasting">FM</a> radio stations transmit from Mobile: <a href="WAVH">WAVH</a>, <a href="WBHY-FM">WBHY</a>, <a href="WBLX-FM">WBLX</a>, <a href="WDLT-FM">WDLT</a>, <a href="WHIL%20%28FM%29">WHIL</a>, <a href="WKSJ-FM">WKSJ</a>, WKSJ-HD2, <a href="WLVM">WLVM</a>, <a href="WMXC">WMXC</a>, <a href="WMXC">WMXC</a>-HD2, <a href="WQUA">WQUA</a>, <a href="WRKH">WRKH</a>, <a href="WRKH">WRKH</a>-HD2, and <a href="WZEW">WZEW</a>. Nine <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM</a> radio stations transmit from Mobile: <a href="WBHY%20%28AM%29">WBHY</a>, <a href="WABF%20%28AM%29">WABF</a>, <a href="WGOK">WGOK</a>, <a href="WIJD">WIJD</a>, <a href="WLPR-AM">WLPR</a>, <a href="WMOB">WMOB</a>, <a href="WNGL">WNGL</a>, <a href="WNTM">WNTM</a>, and <a href="WXQW">WXQW</a>. The content ranges from Christian Contemporary to <a href="Hip%20hop">Hip hop</a> to <a href="Top%2040">Top 40</a>.
In fall of 2020, <a href="Nielsen%20Holdings">Nielsen</a> ranked Mobile's radio market as the 102nd in the US. Some years earlier, Nielsen's predecessor, <a href="Arbitron">Arbitron</a> ranked Mobile's radio market as 93rd in fall 2007.
Sports.
Football.
Mobile is the home of <a href="Ladd%E2%80%93Peebles%20Stadium">Ladd–Peebles Stadium</a>. The <a href="American%20football">football</a> stadium opened in 1948. With a current capacity of 40,646, Ladd–Peebles Stadium is the <a href="List%20of%20American%20football%20stadiums%20by%20capacity">fourth-largest stadium in the state</a>.
Ladd–Peebles Stadium has been home to the <a href="Senior%20Bowl">Senior Bowl</a> since 1951, featuring the best college seniors in <a href="College%20football">NCAA football</a>.
The <a href="Dollar%20General%20Bowl">Dollar General Bowl</a>, originally known as the Mobile Alabama Bowl and later the GMAC Bowl and GoDaddy.com Bowl, has been played at Ladd–Peebles Stadium since 1999. It features opponents from the <a href="Sun%20Belt%20Conference">Sun Belt</a> and <a href="Mid-American%20Conference">Mid-American</a> conferences.
Since 1988, Ladd–Peebles Stadium has hosted the Alabama-Mississippi All-Star Classic. The top graduating high school seniors from their respective states compete each June.
The <a href="University%20of%20South%20Alabama">University of South Alabama</a> in Mobile established a football team in 2007, which went undefeated in its 2009 inaugural season. Their program moved to Division I/FBS in 2013 as a member of the <a href="Sun%20Belt%20Conference">Sun Belt Conference</a>. It currently plays at Ladd–Peebles Stadium.
Baseball.
Mobile's <a href="Hank%20Aaron%20Stadium">Hank Aaron Stadium</a> was the home of the <a href="Mobile%20BayBears">Mobile BayBears</a> <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">Minor League Baseball</a> team from 1997 to 2019. Five members of the <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Baseball Hall of Fame</a> called Mobile home, more than any city outside of New York City and Chicago: the five players were <a href="Satchel%20Paige">Satchel Paige</a>, <a href="Billy%20Williams%20%28left%20fielder%29">Billy Williams</a>, <a href="Willie%20McCovey">Willie McCovey</a>, <a href="Hank%20Aaron">Hank Aaron</a>, and <a href="Ozzie%20Smith">Ozzie Smith</a>. Other baseball players to hail from South Alabama include <a href="Amos%20Otis">Amos Otis</a>, <a href="Tommie%20Agee">Tommie Agee</a>, <a href="Cleon%20Jones">Cleon Jones</a>, <a href="Luis%20Gonzalez%20%28outfielder%2C%20born%201967%29">Luis Gonzalez</a>, <a href="Juan%20Pierre">Juan Pierre</a>, <a href="Jon%20Lieber">Jon Lieber</a>, <a href="Adam%20Lind">Adam Lind</a>, and <a href="David%20Freese">David Freese</a>.
Basketball.
South Alabama basketball is a respected mid-major, regularly competing for the Sun Belt Conference championship. They play their home games at the <a href="Mitchell%20Center">Mitchell Center</a>.
Other sports and facilities.
The Archbishop Lipscomb Athletic Complex is home of <a href="AFC%20Mobile">AFC Mobile</a>, which is a <a href="National%20Premier%20Soccer%20League">National Premier Soccer League</a> team.
The public Mobile Tennis Center includes over 50 courts, all lighted and hard-court.
For golfers, Magnolia Grove, part of the <a href="Robert%20Trent%20Jones%20Golf%20Trail">Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail</a>, has 36 holes. The Falls course was recently named the best par 3 course in America. <a href="The%20Mitchell%20Company%20Tournament%20of%20Champions">The Mitchell Company Tournament of Champions</a> was played annually at Magnolia Grove from 1999 through 2007. The <a href="Mobile%20Bay%20LPGA%20Classic">Mobile Bay LPGA Classic</a> took its place in 2008, also held at Mobile's Magnolia Grove.
Mobile is home to the <a href="Azalea%20Trail%20Run">Azalea Trail Run</a>, which races through historic midtown and downtown Mobile. This 10k run has been an annual event since 1978. The Azalea Trail Run is one of the premier 10k road races in the United States, attracting runners from all over the world.
